prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author's friend has five kids with different fathers and is still single. The friend has been making some pretty hurtful comments to the author over the past two years, asking questions that come off as insults. The author finally responds by pointing out that the friend's situation with five kids and no child support might be why she's having trouble finding a partner. The friend gets angry and hangs up, and now mutual friends are criticizing the author for being privileged and a bad friend.

First, I need to consider the context. The friend's comments were clearly targeting the author's appearance, work, and dating life. The author tried to brush them off with polite responses like telling her to focus on herself. But after repeated insults, the author finally snapped and gave a direct answer about the friend's situation. 

The key issue here is whether the author was justified in responding that way. The friend had been making personal attacks for two years, so it's understandable that the author felt defensive. However, bringing up the five kids and child support could be seen as a sensitive topic. Even though it's the truth, it might be considered a low blow because it's personal and could be hurtful. 

But also, the friend was the one consistently attacking the author, so maybe the author was just pushing back. However, the author's response might have been too harsh, even if the friend started it. Friends are supposed to be supportive, so retaliating with a personal truth could damage the friendship. Additionally, mutual friends are now siding with the friend, which complicates things. 

Another angle is that the author's job in the adult industry is a sensitive topic, and the friend had already tried that job, so maybe the friend felt jealous or insecure. The author's response might have been a way to highlight the friend's own issues, but perhaps it was not the best approach. 

Considering all that, the author might be in the wrong if the response was too harsh and crossed a line, even if they were provoked. Alternatively, if the author was just stating the truth as they see it and defending themselves against ongoing insults, they might not be wrong. But in friendships, even if someone is being mean, responding with a personal attack can backfire. So maybe the answer is A, the author is in the wrong. But I need to check if there's a better way to respond. The author was defensive and wanted to stop the insults, but the method might have been inappropriate. So leaning towards A.
